articles.title: This bonobo had a pretend tea party — showing make believe isn’t just for humans
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 05 February 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00357-7In the first demonstration of pretend play in a non-human, the ape favoured a cup filled with imaginary juice over one with its ‘contents’ emptied.
articles.content:
Kanzi the bonobo, pictured in 2016.Credit: First Run Features/Everett Collection via Alamy

A male bonobo called Kanzi is the first non-human animal to clearly grasp the concept of make believe. In experiments reported today in Science, the ape favoured a cup that scientists had pretended to fill with juice over one they had pretended to empty1.

The study adds to evidence that some animals, including humans’ closest relatives, can conceive of objects, events and individuals that aren’t “in the here and now”, says Amalia Bastos, a comparative psychologist at the University of St Andrews University, UK, who co-authored the study with cognitive scientist Christopher Krupenye at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland.

“It tells us that maybe they have a richer inner mental life than some people might have given them credit for or expected,” she adds.

Imaginary blueberries

Researchers have observed behaviour that resembles pretending in chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes) as well as bonobos (Pan paniscus) and other great apes. A captive bonobo named Panbanisha was observed making a plucking motion to a picture of blueberries and then moving her fingers to her mouth, as if to eat the imaginary fruit2. Researchers have also documented wild chimpanzees carrying logs like dolls, especially in young females3.

To explicitly test whether apes can exhibit pretence, Bastos and Krupenye adapted a ‘tea party’ task used in children, who usually start to imagine pretend objects around the age of 2–3 years. The test was made easier, because Kanzi — who died in 2025 aged 44 — can understand hundreds of English words and use symbols known as lexigrams, to communicate. “We were all a bit starstruck because Kanzi has been a celebrity for a very long time in the field of animal cognition,” Bastos says.

Once Kanzi learnt to choose a transparent cup filled with actual juice over an empty one, the researchers moved onto the tea-party task. An experimenter showed Kanzi two cups and then pretended to fill them from an empty jug. After inverting one cup — to ‘empty’ its imaginary contents — Kanzi was asked to pick a cup. The ape selected the ‘full’ cup in 34 of 50 trials, which is well above the number of times expected if his choices were random. In a similar task involving grapes, Kanzi went for pretend fruit in 69% of trials.

Proof of pretending
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery that a bonobo demonstrated the ability to engage in pretend play, previously thought to be unique to humans. This finding broadens our understanding of animal cognition and suggests a richer inner mental life in great apes, which has broad implications for science and our perception of animal intelligence. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful breakthrough in animal cognition research.
articles.personality_title: Bonobo Kanzi shows first clear example of pretend play in animals
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Pretend play, like imagining objects or events that aren’t really there, has long been seen as a unique ability of young children. Scientists have wondered if animals, especially our close relatives like bonobos, can also imagine things that don’t exist in the moment.

**What happened** – A bonobo named Kanzi, who lived until 2025, took part in a test where he was shown two clear cups. Although both cups looked empty, the researchers pretended to fill one with juice and empty the other. Kanzi chose the ‘full’ cup more often than chance would allow, showing he understood the pretend scenario. In another test with grapes, he also chose the imaginary fruit most of the time.

**Impact** – This is the first strong proof that an animal other than humans can clearly imagine things that aren’t really there. It shows that bonobos like Kanzi may have a richer mental life than scientists previously thought. This discovery helps us understand animal thinking better and challenges the idea that pretend play is only for humans.

**What’s next step** – Researchers will likely explore pretend play in other animals and study how this ability develops. They may also look into how such mental skills help animals in the wild and how they communicate or solve problems.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Kanzi the bonobo’s ability to choose imaginary juice in a test proves that animals can engage in pretend play, a mental skill once thought to be only human.
articles.personality_title_fr: Kanzi le bonobo montre le premier exemple clair de jeu d’imagination chez les animaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le jeu d’imagination, comme imaginer des objets ou des événements qui ne sont pas réels, est souvent considéré comme une capacité unique des jeunes enfants. Les scientifiques se demandent si les animaux, notamment nos proches parents comme les bonobos, peuvent aussi imaginer des choses qui n’existent pas sur le moment.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un bonobo nommé Kanzi, décédé en 2025, a participé à un test où on lui montrait deux tasses transparentes. Bien que les deux tasses semblaient vides, les chercheurs ont fait semblant d’en remplir une de jus et de vider l’autre. Kanzi a choisi la tasse « pleine » plus souvent que le hasard ne le permettrait, montrant qu’il comprenait la situation imaginaire. Dans un autre test avec des raisins, il a aussi choisi le fruit imaginaire la plupart du temps.

**Impact** – C’est la première preuve solide qu’un animal autre que l’humain peut clairement imaginer des choses qui ne sont pas réelles. Cela montre que les bonobos comme Kanzi ont peut-être une vie mentale plus riche que ce que pensaient les scientifiques. Cette découverte aide à mieux comprendre la pensée animale et remet en question l’idée que le jeu d’imagination est réservé aux humains.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont probablement étudier le jeu d’imagination chez d’autres animaux et comment cette capacité se développe. Ils pourront aussi examiner comment ces compétences mentales aident les animaux dans la nature, dans leur communication ou pour résoudre des problèmes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La capacité de Kanzi le bonobo à choisir du jus imaginaire prouve que les animaux peuvent jouer à faire semblant, une compétence mentale autrefois considérée comme uniquement humaine.
articles.personality_title_es: Kanzi el bonobo muestra el primer ejemplo claro de juego de imaginación en animales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El juego de imaginación, como imaginar objetos o eventos que no están presentes, se ha visto como una habilidad única de los niños pequeños. Los científicos se han preguntado si los animales, especialmente nuestros parientes cercanos como los bonobos, también pueden imaginar cosas que no existen en el momento.

**Qué pasó** – Un bonobo llamado Kanzi, que vivió hasta 2025, participó en una prueba donde le mostraron dos vasos transparentes. Aunque ambos vasos parecían vacíos, los investigadores fingieron llenar uno con jugo y vaciar el otro. Kanzi eligió el vaso “lleno” más veces de lo que el azar permitiría, mostrando que entendía la situación imaginaria. En otra prueba con uvas, también eligió la fruta imaginaria la mayoría de las veces.

**Impacto** – Esta es la primera prueba clara de que un animal que no es humano puede imaginar cosas que no están realmente allí. Esto muestra que los bonobos como Kanzi podrían tener una vida mental más rica de lo que se pensaba. Este descubrimiento ayuda a entender mejor el pensamiento animal y cuestiona la idea de que el juego de imaginación es solo humano.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores probablemente explorarán el juego de imaginación en otros animales y cómo se desarrolla esta habilidad. También podrían estudiar cómo estas destrezas mentales ayudan a los animales en la naturaleza y cómo se comunican o resuelven problemas.

**Resumen en una frase** – La habilidad de Kanzi el bonobo para elegir jugo imaginario en una prueba demuestra que los animales pueden jugar a imaginar, una habilidad mental que antes se creía solo humana.

articles.title: Milano Cortina 2026
articles.summary: About 2,900 Olympic athletes have converged on northern Italy to sort out who is the GOAT—or perhaps the stoat.
articles.content:
December 8, 2025

No Olympic competitions covers more ground than the 50-kilometer cross-country ski races. The grueling event takes more than 2 hours to complete, requiring competitors to ski a distance longer than a marathon. That's still, however, less than an eighth of the distance between the two official host cities of the 2026 Winter Olympics and Paralympics—Milan and Cortina d’Ampezzo.

With events spread across more than 22,000 square kilometers (8,500 square miles) and eight cities or towns in northern Italy, these are the most geographically dispersed Games in Olympic history. The decentralized design was intentional, allowing planners to control costs and make the event more sustainable by using existing venues rather than constructing several expensive new facilities. More than 90 percent of the venues are existing or temporary facilities, including some refurbished facilities that were used in the 1956 Cortina d’Ampezzo Games.

About 2,900 athletes will compete across 116 events over 19 days in 13 venues in what will be the third time Italy has hosted the Games. Several of the key event venues are visible in these satellite images of the two largest host cities—Milan and Verona. The OLI (Operational Land Imager) on Landsat 8 and 9 captured the images on December 8 and 9, 2025, respectively.

Olympic festivities will kick off officially on February 6 at San Siro Stadium with performances by pop star Mariah Carey, classical singer Andrea Bocelli, classical instrumentalist Lang Lang, and Italian singer-songwriter Laura Pausini. Built in 1925, San Siro is Italy's largest stadium and the longtime home of renowned football clubs AC Milan and Inter Milan.

December 9, 2025

Milan will mostly host indoor ice events in several other venues around the city. Ice hockey will be spread across two venues, the Milano Santagiulia Ice Hockey Arena and the temporary Milano Rho Ice Hockey Arena. The former, located east of the city in the green and residential Santa Giulia district, is the only new permanent venue constructed for the Games. The latter, in Milano Ice Park, is a temporary transformation of the Fiera Milano Rho exhibition center, a complex of pavilions and a convention center northwest of the city center.

Speed skating and figure skating will be in the Milano Ice Skating Arena, an 11,500-person stadium in Assago, a small town just outside of Milan. Outside of the Olympics, the multisport facility is used by a skating school and basketball team and as a venue for tennis, squash, swimming, and several other sports.

The February 22 closing ceremonies will take place in Verona, a city of about 250,000 people 150 kilometers east of Milan, in Verona Arena, an ancient Roman amphitheater that was built between the 1st and 3rd centuries. What was once used for animal hunts and gladiator battles will serve as the backdrop for musicians, dancers, and artists in a ceremony that organizers say will honor the spirit of athletics and Italy’s rich cultural heritage. The arena, with a seating capacity of about 22,000, is the third-largest surviving amphitheater in Europe and unusually well-preserved.

New events this year will include men's and women's ski mountaineering, skeleton mixed team relay, women's doubles luge, freestyle skiing dual moguls, and women's large hill ski jumping. The 2026 Olympic mascots are Tina and Milo, a brother-and-sister pair of cheerful, scarf-wearing animated stoats with names inspired by Milan and Cortina. Stoats, also called ermine, are fierce predators in the weasel family known for reportedly mesmerizing prey with energetic dances and for having fur that changes from dark brown in the summer to white in the winter. In Italy, stoats typically live in the mountains above 3,500 meters (11,500 feet).

NASA Earth Observatory image by Lauren Dauphin, using Landsat data from the U.S. Geological Survey. Story by Adam Voiland.

articles.personality_title: Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Games blend sport, history, and sustainability
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The 2026 Winter Olympics and Paralympics will be held in northern Italy, hosted by Milan and Cortina d’Ampezzo. These Games stand out for their wide geographic spread and focus on using mostly existing sports venues to reduce costs and environmental impact.

**What happened** – About 2,900 athletes are set to compete in 116 events across 13 venues from February 6 to 22, 2026. The events will take place in eight cities covering more than 22,000 square kilometers. The Games will open at Milan’s historic San Siro Stadium with performances by famous artists. Most ice events will happen in Milan, including hockey and skating, while the closing ceremony will be held at Verona’s ancient Roman amphitheater, the Verona Arena.

**Impact** – This edition of the Winter Olympics is the most spread out in history, using over 90% existing or temporary venues to save money and reduce environmental damage. This approach highlights how large events can be organized sustainably. The mix of modern sports and historic sites like Verona Arena connects athletic competition with Italy’s rich culture. New sports like ski mountaineering and mixed team skeleton will add fresh excitement.

**What's next step** – As the Games approach, final preparations will focus on readying venues and ensuring smooth coordination across the wide area. The success of these Olympics may influence future hosts to prioritize sustainability and cultural heritage when planning.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics combine sports, history, and smart planning to create a large but environmentally thoughtful global event.
articles.personality_title_fr: Jeux d’hiver Milano Cortina 2026 : sport, histoire et durabilité réunis
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les Jeux olympiques et paralympiques d’hiver 2026 se tiendront dans le nord de l’Italie, à Milan et Cortina d’Ampezzo. Ces Jeux se distinguent par leur grande étendue géographique et leur utilisation majoritaire d’installations sportives existantes pour réduire les coûts et l’impact environnemental.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Environ 2 900 athlètes participeront à 116 épreuves dans 13 sites du 6 au 22 février 2026. Les compétitions se dérouleront dans huit villes couvrant plus de 22 000 kilomètres carrés. Les Jeux s’ouvriront au stade historique San Siro de Milan avec des spectacles d’artistes célèbres. La plupart des épreuves sur glace auront lieu à Milan, tandis que la cérémonie de clôture se tiendra dans l’arène romaine antique de Vérone.

**Impact** – Cette édition des Jeux d’hiver est la plus étendue de l’histoire, utilisant plus de 90 % de sites existants ou temporaires pour économiser de l’argent et réduire les dégâts environnementaux. Cette approche montre comment organiser de grands événements de façon durable. L’association des sports modernes et des sites historiques comme l’arène de Vérone relie la compétition sportive à la riche culture italienne. De nouveaux sports comme le ski-alpinisme et le relais mixte en skeleton apporteront une touche de nouveauté.

**Étape suivante** – À l’approche des Jeux, les préparatifs finaux porteront sur la mise en état des sites et la coordination sur ce vaste territoire. Le succès de ces Jeux pourra inspirer d’autres organisateurs à privilégier durabilité et patrimoine culturel.

**En une phrase** – Les Jeux d’hiver Milano Cortina 2026 allient sport, histoire et organisation intelligente pour un grand événement mondial respectueux de l’environnement.
articles.personality_title_es: Juegos de Invierno Milano Cortina 2026: deporte, historia y sostenibilidad unidos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los Juegos Olímpicos y Paralímpicos de Invierno 2026 se celebrarán en el norte de Italia, con sede en Milán y Cortina d’Ampezzo. Estos Juegos destacan por su gran extensión geográfica y por usar principalmente instalaciones deportivas ya existentes para reducir costos y el impacto ambiental.

**Qué pasó** – Unos 2,900 atletas competirán en 116 eventos en 13 sedes del 6 al 22 de febrero de 2026. Las competencias se realizarán en ocho ciudades que cubren más de 22,000 kilómetros cuadrados. Los Juegos comenzarán en el histórico estadio San Siro de Milán con presentaciones de artistas famosos. La mayoría de los eventos sobre hielo serán en Milán, mientras que la ceremonia de clausura será en el antiguo anfiteatro romano de Verona.

**Impacto** – Esta edición de los Juegos de Invierno es la más dispersa en la historia, usando más del 90 % de sedes existentes o temporales para ahorrar dinero y reducir daños ambientales. Este enfoque muestra cómo se pueden organizar grandes eventos de forma sostenible. La combinación de deportes modernos y sitios históricos como la Arena de Verona conecta la competencia deportiva con la rica cultura italiana. Nuevos deportes como esquí de montaña y relevo mixto en skeleton añadirán novedades.

**Próximo paso** – Conforme se acerquen los Juegos, los preparativos finales se centrarán en dejar listas las sedes y asegurar la coordinación en esta gran área. El éxito de estos Juegos podría influir en futuros anfitriones para que prioricen la sostenibilidad y el patrimonio cultural.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los Juegos de Invierno Milano Cortina 2026 combinan deporte, historia y planificación inteligente para un gran evento global respetuoso con el medio ambiente.
